ratings.comment: Mr Dai explains things very clear. He tells funny stories in between subjects. His class is great.
Prof Dai is an amazing teacher. He understands the struggle students go through and is helpful. Prof Dai is hilarious and just a great guy.
Prof. Dai is incredibly knowledgable about the material. One of the best professors I've had at UW.

The class was based on 3 exams. Prof. Dai knows how to make the subject matter interesting and gives students a chance to improve their grade while still expecting a lot out of students. Very great teacher!
Professor Dai is hilarious and always gives real-world examples of how statistics are used in practice. I was engaged throughout the class.
Engaging lectures, a manageable workload. A must-take for stats majors or anyone looking to get into data science/machine learning.
Prof Dai is very good at teaching. Nice examples, detailed explanations, and useful practical tricks make this introductory course really helpful.

Very Good Professor! He tried very hard to explain everything and always ask us whether we understand him or not. He managed to make somewhat dry materials more interesting! I like him a lot. By far my favorite professor!

Language barrier was tough in the first unit but it became easier as the semester went on. The guy is a literal genius. Gives you the material you need if you go to lecture. If you listen during class you'll be fine. Homework can be dense but it is manageable. Funny guy too

Lecture isnt mandatory but it actually helped a lot. In lecture he tells you everything you will need to know to do well on the exams. Making note sheet straight from the lecture slides was key for the exams. Overall liked him a lot.

There was a large disconnect between the material on lectures and homework and exams, but I felt that much of the exams were based on lecture material. I would highly recommend going because he did examples in class that aren't on the lecture slides. Overall, Xiaowu is not very good at answering questions and lectures felt really slow.

Didn't miss a single lecture and still had to look up every equation in the book in order to complete the homework. Exams were very difficult, very heavily weighted, and were based solely on lecture material rather than the book. Professor Dai was also very ineffective at answering questions and getting his points across in an understandable way.

Homeworks were all repetitive and took a very long time. Exams were unnecessarily difficult. Class averages on the exams were 65% and 59%. Content on the exams weren't based on things in the book; they were solely on lecture material, and lecture notes weren't posted. This would be fine if mistakes weren't made during lecture.
